info.title: Pricing Engine API
info.description: API for a pricing engine that is called by the enfore platform

post.summary: Get a pricing based on a pricing engine context in the given organisation

parameters.name: org-id
parameters.description: ID of the organization whose data is being accessed.

register_id.description:
The technical identifier of the device where the order is processed assigned
by the enfore platform.

operator_id.description:
The technical identifier of the cashier who is processing the order assigned
by the enfore platform.

sales_channel_id.description:
The technical identifier of the store where the order is processed assigned
by the enfore platform.

customer_id.description: The technical identifier of the customer assigned by the enfore platform.

sales_orders_id.description: The ID of the order that this PricingEngineContext corresponds to.

base_price_and_quantity.description:
The set of information defining the price of a product.
A product's price is always relative to a specific quantity of the product.
For example, if a single bottle of water costs 1, 5 bottles cost 5.
Additionally, a given price might be including tax or not.
Therefore, the ProductPriceAndQuantity is a combination of a quantity, a price and a "price is gross"-flag.

order_date.description: Order date, i.e. when the item was added to the order, in date-time notation in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

taxes.description: List of taxes that were applied to the item

items.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968  30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968  31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978  30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979  30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983  31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993  31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998  31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007  current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

type.description:
The type of the additional information.
May be used by custom document templates to determine position and
formatting of information.

text.description:
The text of the additional information broken into parts.
The default document template will treat each part as a paragraph.
Custom document templates may have specialized handling per part.

items.description:
Addition information for an order or line item that is to be printed on
the invoice(s) for the order/item.

description.description: Description text for the pricing result.

checksum.description:
Optional checksum. Will be returned to the external pricing engine
on subsequent calls and can be used to detect whether the item/order
was changed (e.g., modified quantity, modified price)

external_data.description:
Optional external data. Will be made available by the plaform as part of the
ERP API's Invoice/InvoiceItem.

last_pricing_status.description:
Status flag and, when necessary, description, checksum and external_data
for of a PricingEngineResult or PricingEngineResultItem.

item_id.description: The ID of the other item.

dependency.description:
Marks the item as being dependent on another item.
That is, the item cannot stand on its own and is a "sub item" of the other item.

items.description:
Line item input for external pricing engine.

The item will always specfiy the product and the quantity of the product
via `product_id` and `quantity`.

When a price is available (configured on the resource, manually entered
by the user or computed by a previous call to external pricing), it will
be provided via the `base_price_and_quantity` field.
When not available, `base_price_and_quantity` will be empty and the base
price must be computed by the external pricing logic.
If the price was manually entered by the user, the flag `price_is_manual`
will be TRUE.

items.description:
Addition information for an order or line item that is to be printed on
the invoice(s) for the order/item.

Output of the external pricing logic with the computed price and
discounts/markups for a line item. Must reference one of the input items.

For each input item (`PricingEngineContextLineItem`), the `PricingEngineResult`
must contain exactly one `PricingEngineResultItem`.

If the price was computed successfully and the line item is otherwise ok,
the `pricing_status` must be `SUCCESS` and `base_price_and_quantity` must
be provided.

The price is given as a computed price in the form of a price per quantity
via the `base_price_and_quantity` field. For example, when the user purchases 10x
bottles of water and the price is 2 per 5 bottles, the logic should return
`{"price": 2, "quantity": 5x}`. The enforePOS side will handle the adjustment to
the actual 10x quantity.

The price might be marked as "manually entered by a user" via the `price_is_manual`
flag.

The provided price must NOT include discounts/markups.

When the external logic cannot compute a price, due to some business reason/constraint
(e.g., customer is not allowed to purchase the specified quantity of product), the field
`pricing_status` must be `BUSINESS_CONSTRAINT_VIOLATION` and must contain a human readable
`description` that will be presented to the end user as part of the client UI.

In case of a technical failure (e.g., database could not be reached), the field
`pricing_status` must be `TECHNICAL_FAILURE` and may contain a human readable
`description` that, when present, will be presented to the end user as part of the client UI.

When the pricing status is not `SUCCESS`, both `base_price_and_quantity` and `manual_price`
can, but need not be, left empty.

unchanged_items.description:
When an item was previously computed and the pricing logic determines that there
is no change needed, it may return the item's ID as part of the `unchanged_items`
list.
The enfore platform will reuse the existing pricing data for that item then.

item_id.description: The ID of the other item.

dependency.description:
Marks the item as being dependent on another item.
That is, the item cannot stand on its own and is a "sub item" of the other item.

temp_item_id.description:
A temporary item ID for use when the item is to be referenced by
another item in a relationship (i.e., `dependency`).
The ID is only valid for the result structure it is part of an will
be replaced by the enforePOS platform with a regular item ID once the
item is created.
The ID must not collide with any other temporary or real item IDs used
in the response.

schema.description:
Result of pricing computation.

For each input item, the result must either contain a matching `PricingEngineResultItem` in `items`
or the ID of the item must be listed under `unchanged_items`.

Additionally, the pricing logic may return new items via `additional_items`.

title.description:

Note that this is not specific to the specific problem occurrence but only depends on the type.
Target audience is developers using the API, not suitable for display to end users.

detail.description:

Target audience is developers using the API, not suitable for display to end users.

on_resource.description: URI of the resource for which the error occurred.

schema.description:
A problem that occurred while processing an API request.
This is based on problem+json as defined in [RFC7807](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7807)
Will have a textual message that is intended for use by developers using the API and not usable for display to end users.
If the error occurred as part of operating on a specific resource, the object may provide the URI idenifying that object.

base_price_and_quantity.description:
The set of information defining the price of a product.
A product's price is always relative to a specific quantity of the product.
For example, if a single bottle of water costs 1, 5 bottles cost 5.
Additionally, a given price might be including tax or not.
Therefore, the ProductPriceAndQuantity is a combination of a quantity, a price and a "price is gross"-flag.

order_date.description: Order date, i.e. when the item was added to the order, in date-time notation in UTC. The date-time notation as defined by RFC 3339 (https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3339.txt), section 5.6, with the "Z" as time-offset. For example, 2017-07-21T17:32:28.123Z

taxes.description: List of taxes that were applied to the item

items.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968  30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968  31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978  30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979  30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983  31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993  31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998  31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007  current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.

The type of the additional information.
May be used by custom document templates to determine position and
formatting of information.

text.description:
The text of the additional information broken into parts.
The default document template will treat each part as a paragraph.
Custom document templates may have specialized handling per part.

items.description:
Addition information for an order or line item that is to be printed on
the invoice(s) for the order/item.

description.description: Description text for the pricing result.

checksum.description:
Optional checksum. Will be returned to the external pricing engine
on subsequent calls and can be used to detect whether the item/order
was changed (e.g., modified quantity, modified price)

external_data.description:
Optional external data. Will be made available by the plaform as part of the
ERP API's Invoice/InvoiceItem.

last_pricing_status.description:
Status flag and, when necessary, description, checksum and external_data
for of a PricingEngineResult or PricingEngineResultItem.

item_id.description: The ID of the other item.

dependency.description:
Marks the item as being dependent on another item.
That is, the item cannot stand on its own and is a "sub item" of the other item.

items.description:
Line item input for external pricing engine.

The item will always specfiy the product and the quantity of the product
via `product_id` and `quantity`.

When a price is available (configured on the resource, manually entered
by the user or computed by a previous call to external pricing), it will
be provided via the `base_price_and_quantity` field.
When not available, `base_price_and_quantity` will be empty and the base
price must be computed by the external pricing logic.
If the price was manually entered by the user, the flag `price_is_manual`
will be TRUE.

items.description:
Addition information for an order or line item that is to be printed on
the invoice(s) for the order/item.

Output of the external pricing logic with the computed price and
discounts/markups for a line item. Must reference one of the input items.

For each input item (`PricingEngineContextLineItem`), the `PricingEngineResult`
must contain exactly one `PricingEngineResultItem`.

If the price was computed successfully and the line item is otherwise ok,
the `pricing_status` must be `SUCCESS` and `base_price_and_quantity` must
be provided.

The price is given as a computed price in the form of a price per quantity
via the `base_price_and_quantity` field. For example, when the user purchases 10x
bottles of water and the price is 2 per 5 bottles, the logic should return
`{"price": 2, "quantity": 5x}`. The enforePOS side will handle the adjustment to
the actual 10x quantity.

The price might be marked as "manually entered by a user" via the `price_is_manual`
flag.

The provided price must NOT include discounts/markups.

When the external logic cannot compute a price, due to some business reason/constraint
(e.g., customer is not allowed to purchase the specified quantity of product), the field
`pricing_status` must be `BUSINESS_CONSTRAINT_VIOLATION` and must contain a human readable
`description` that will be presented to the end user as part of the client UI.

In case of a technical failure (e.g., database could not be reached), the field
`pricing_status` must be `TECHNICAL_FAILURE` and may contain a human readable
`description` that, when present, will be presented to the end user as part of the client UI.

When the pricing status is not `SUCCESS`, both `base_price_and_quantity` and `manual_price`
can, but need not be, left empty.

unchanged_items.description:
When an item was previously computed and the pricing logic determines that there
is no change needed, it may return the item's ID as part of the `unchanged_items`
list.
The enfore platform will reuse the existing pricing data for that item then.

item_id.description: The ID of the other item.

dependency.description:
Marks the item as being dependent on another item.
That is, the item cannot stand on its own and is a "sub item" of the other item.

temp_item_id.description:
A temporary item ID for use when the item is to be referenced by
another item in a relationship (i.e., `dependency`).
The ID is only valid for the result structure it is part of an will
be replaced by the enforePOS platform with a regular item ID once the
item is created.
The ID must not collide with any other temporary or real item IDs used
in the response.

type.description:
The type of the additional information.
May be used by custom document templates to determine position and
formatting of information.

text.description:
The text of the additional information broken into parts.
The default document template will treat each part as a paragraph.
Custom document templates may have specialized handling per part.

items.description:

the invoice(s) for the order/item.

PricingEngineResultAdditionalItem.description:
Structure for new line items produced by the external pricing logic.

Must have a valid price via `base_price_and_quantity`.

type.description: A URI reference [RFC3986] that identifies the problem type.

title.description:
A short, human-readable summary of the problem type.
Note that this is not specific to the specific problem occurrence but only depends on the type.
Target audience is developers using the API, not suitable for display to end users.

detail.description:
A human-readable explanation specific to this occurrence of the problem.
Target audience is developers using the API, not suitable for display to end users.

on_resource.description: URI of the resource for which the error occurred.

Problem.description:
A problem that occurred while processing an API request.
This is based on problem+json as defined in [RFC7807](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7807)
Will have a textual message that is intended for use by developers using the API and not usable for display to end users.
If the error occurred as part of operating on a specific resource, the object may provide the URI idenifying that object.

ProductPriceAndQuantity.description:
The set of information defining the price of a product.
A product's price is always relative to a specific quantity of the product.
For example, if a single bottle of water costs 1, 5 bottles cost 5.
Additionally, a given price might be including tax or not.
Therefore, the ProductPriceAndQuantity is a combination of a quantity, a price and a "price is gross"-flag.

Tax.description:
A Tax represents a specific and unchangeable tax. Whenever a tax (rate) changes due to new legislation
or other reasons, a new Tax must be defined and used from then on.

For example, the standard VAT rates in Germany have been changed multiple times in the last 50 years:
* 01.01.1968  30.06.1968 = 10%
* 01.07.1968  31.12.1977 = 11%
* 01.01.1978  30.06.1979 = 12%
* 01.07.1979  30.06.1983 = 13%
* 01.07.1983  31.12.1992 = 14%
* 01.01.1993  31.03.1998 = 15%
* 01.04.1998  31.12.2006 = 16%
* 01.01.2007  current    = 19%

For now, we only use the tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2007. But if, hypothetically, Germany would increase its
standard VAT rate to 21% on 1/JAN/2020, we would define a new tax DE_STANDARD_VAT_2020 and use that from
1/JAN/2020 on.
